title: Time-Travel Graph Diffing
description:
Compare graph structure across git commits to understand how the project evolved and detect structural regressions.

## Background & Motivation
Since beads are stored in git, we have full history available. Questions like 'What changed since last week?' or 'Did my changes introduce a bottleneck?' are answerable but not currently exposed.

## Value Proposition
- For Humans: Visualize progress, understand what changed during a sprint, postmortem analysis
- For AI Agents: Structural regression detection - validate changes before committing

## Technical Approach
1. Add git history loader (read files at specific commit)
2. Create snapshot comparison logic
3. Generate diff report (new/closed issues, metric changes, new cycles)
4. CLI: --diff-since <commit|date> and --as-of <commit|date>
5. TUI: Highlight changed items

## Key Features
- Load historical state without checking out
- Compare metrics (PageRank, betweenness) between snapshots
- Detect new cycles or bottlenecks
- 'What would change if I close these issues?' simulation

title: Impact Radar & Drift Alerts
description:
Detect significant changes in graph metrics and alert when structure degrades.

## Background & Motivation
Graph metrics (PageRank, betweenness, cycles) can degrade over time without anyone noticing. A new cycle might be introduced, or a bottleneck might emerge. Proactive detection prevents issues from compounding.

## Value Proposition
- For Humans: Early warning when project health degrades
- For AI Agents: Validate changes before committing - 'did I introduce a cycle?'

## Technical Approach
1. Baseline storage (snapshot of metrics at a point in time)
2. Drift calculator (compare current to baseline)
3. Threshold configuration (when to alert)
4. CLI: --check-drift for CI integration

## Alert Types
- New cycles detected (critical)
- Significant PageRank changes (potential new bottleneck)
- Betweenness spike (new critical path node)
- Density increase (complexity growing)

## Success Criteria
- CI can run --check-drift and fail on regressions
- Clear exit codes: 0=OK, 1=critical, 2=warning
- Human-readable and JSON output available

description: .bv/baseline.json stores metrics snapshot. --save-baseline creates. --baseline-info shows. Includes commit annotation.

description: Compare current to baseline. Detect: new cycles (critical), PageRank changes (warning), density growth (info). Configurable thresholds in .bv/drift.yaml.

title: Semantic Vector Search
description:
Add natural language search via vector embeddings, enabling queries like 'memory leak issues' to find relevant results even without exact keyword matches.

## Background & Motivation
Current search is regex-based, requiring exact matches. Users want to search by meaning, not just keywords. AI agents benefit from semantic retrieval for RAG patterns.

## Value Proposition
- For Humans: 'that thing about memory leaks' actually finds it
- For AI Agents: RAG over project history - 'how did we solve similar issues before?'

## Technical Approach
1. Local embeddings (start simple: sentence-transformers via subprocess or pure Go)
2. Vector storage (sqlite-vec extension or simple flat file)
3. Incremental indexing (embed on first access, update when issues change)
4. Semantic search mode in CLI and TUI

## Scope Control
Start minimal:
- Embed title + description only
- Single embedding model
- Top-10 results
- No hybrid search initially

## Dependencies & Risks
- Embedding model choice affects quality and size
- May require external tool (Python) initially
- Could start with Go-native solution later

title: AI-Aware Kanban Autoprioritizer
description:
Use graph metrics (PageRank, betweenness, freshness, blocker count) to suggest priority adjustments and surface high-impact items.

## Background & Motivation
The analysis package computes rich metrics but they're only visible in the insights panel. Users and agents want actionable recommendations: 'These 5 items should be prioritized because they unblock the most work.'

## Value Proposition
- For Humans: 'Smart suggestions' that explain why items should be reprioritized
- For AI Agents: --robot-priority provides a ranked work queue with reasoning

## Technical Approach
1. Create priority scoring function combining multiple metrics
2. Generate recommendations comparing current vs suggested priority
3. CLI: --robot-priority outputs priority-ranked JSON with explanations
4. TUI: 'Suggested' badge/indicator on items

## Scoring Function
impact_score = (
    0.3 * normalized_pagerank +
    0.3 * normalized_betweenness +
    0.2 * blocker_count / max_blocker_count +
    0.1 * freshness_penalty +
    0.1 * explicit_priority_boost
)

title: Implement priority scoring function
description:
Create composite scoring combining PageRank (30%), Betweenness (30%), Blocker count (20%), Staleness (10%), Explicit priority (10%).

## Algorithm
func (a *Analyzer) ComputeImpactScore(issue *model.Issue) ImpactScore:
  - Normalize all metrics to 0-1 range
  - Apply weights: 0.3*pagerank + 0.3*betweenness + 0.2*blockerRatio + 0.1*staleness + 0.1*priorityBoost
  - Return: IssueID, ImpactScore, ScoreBreakdown map

## Staleness Penalty
- Days since update, normalized: min(daysSinceUpdate / 30, 1.0)
- Older items get slight penalty to surface them

## Priority Boost
- P0=1.0, P1=0.75, P2=0.5, P3=0.25, P4=0.0 (higher priority = higher boost)

## File Changes
- pkg/analysis/priority.go: New scoring logic
- pkg/analysis/priority_test.go: Tests with known values

title: Generate priority recommendations with explanations
description:
Compare impact scores to current priorities and generate actionable recommendations.

## Output Structure
type PriorityRecommendation struct {
    IssueID           string
    CurrentPriority   int
    SuggestedPriority int
    ImpactScore       float64
    Confidence        float64  // 0-1, higher when score difference is large
    Reasoning         []string // Human-readable explanations
}

## Reasoning Templates
- 'Blocks N high-priority items' (when UnblocksCount > 2)
- 'Critical path bottleneck' (when Betweenness > 0.5)
- 'High centrality in graph' (when PageRank > 0.3)
- 'Stale for N days' (when staleness penalty applied)

## Confidence Calculation
- Large score vs priority mismatch = high confidence
- Multiple reasoning factors = higher confidence
- Single weak signal = low confidence

title: Topological Work-Plan Generator
description:
Leverage the existing DAG analysis to generate linearized, dependency-respecting work plans. This is the highest-value feature because it directly answers the question every developer and AI agent asks: 'What can I actually work on right now?'

## Background & Motivation
The analysis package already computes TopologicalOrder via topo.Sort(). However, this raw ordering isn't directly actionable because:
1. It includes closed issues
2. It doesn't filter to 'leaf nodes' (tasks with no open blockers)
3. It's not exposed via CLI for programmatic access

## Value Proposition
- For Humans: A 'Smart To-Do' view showing only actionable items eliminates cognitive overhead of scanning blocked tasks.
- For AI Agents: --robot-plan enables autonomous workflows where agents can request a strictly ordered task list, preventing work on blocked items.

## Technical Approach
1. Add GetActionableIssues() to analysis package - returns issues where all blocking dependencies are closed
2. Add GetExecutionPlan() - returns topologically sorted actionable items with parallel tracks identified
3. CLI flag --robot-plan outputs JSON with execution order
4. TUI view showing actionable items grouped by parallel tracks

## Success Criteria
- Agent can request plan and receive valid execution order
- Plan respects all blocking dependencies
- Parallel tracks (independent work streams) are identified
- Zero actionable items shown when all open issues are blocked

title: Add GetActionableIssues() to analysis package
description:
Identify issues that can be worked on immediately - those with no open blocking dependencies.

## Algorithm
func (a *Analyzer) GetActionableIssues() []model.Issue:
  - Skip closed issues
  - Skip issues with open blockers (only 'blocks' type creates hard deps)
  - Missing blockers don't block (graceful degradation)

## Key Design Decisions
1. Only 'blocks' type creates hard dependencies - 'related' and 'parent-child' are informational
2. Missing blockers don't block - Graceful degradation when referenced issue doesn't exist
3. Closed issues are never actionable - They're done

## File Changes
- pkg/analysis/graph.go: Add methods to Analyzer struct
- pkg/analysis/graph_test.go: Add comprehensive tests

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Returns only open/in_progress/blocked issues
- [ ] Correctly identifies issues with no open blockers
- [ ] Handles missing dependency references gracefully
- [ ] Handles cycles gracefully
- [ ] Unit tests cover all edge cases

title: Add GetExecutionPlan() with parallel track detection
description:
Generate a dependency-respecting execution plan with parallel tracks identified for concurrent work.

## Data Structure
type ExecutionPlan struct {
    Tracks []ExecutionTrack
    Total  int
}

type ExecutionTrack struct {
    TrackID string
    Items   []PlanItem
    Reason  string  // Why these are grouped
}

type PlanItem struct {
    ID          string
    Title       string
    Priority    int
    UnblocksIDs []string  // What becomes actionable when done
}

## Algorithm
1. Get actionable issues from GetActionableIssues()
2. Identify connected components among actionable issues
3. Within each component, sort by priority then topological order
4. For each item, compute what it unblocks

## Considerations
- Parallel Tracks: Independent subgraphs can be worked on concurrently
- Unblocks Info: Helps prioritize - 'doing X unblocks 5 other tasks'
- Priority Integration: Within tracks, respect explicit priority

## File Changes

- pkg/analysis/plan_test.go: Tests

title: Context Packs & Recipes System
description:
Implement named workflow presets ('recipes') that bundle filters, layouts, and exports into one-command operations. This dramatically simplifies common workflows for both humans and AI agents.

## Background & Motivation
Users repeatedly perform the same sequences: 'Show me blocked high-priority items' or 'Export a release changelog'. Currently this requires remembering multiple flags. Recipes encode these patterns.

## Value Proposition
- For Humans: 'bv --recipe triage' replaces 'bv --status open,blocked --priority 0,1 --sort priority'
- For AI Agents: Recipes provide semantic entry points - 'triage mode' vs 'release mode' vs 'dependency analysis mode'

## Technical Approach
1. Define recipe schema (YAML)
2. Embed sensible default recipes
3. Allow user-defined recipes in .bv/recipes.yaml
4. CLI: bv --recipe <name> or bv -r <name>
5. TUI: Recipe picker with descriptions

## Built-in Recipes
- triage: Open/blocked issues, sorted by priority
- release-cut: Recently closed issues for changelog
- blocked-review: All blocked items with blocker info
- dependency-risk: High betweenness/PageRank items
- quick-wins: Low-priority, no-dependency items
- stale: Items not updated in 14+ days

    filters:
      status: [open, blocked]
      priority_max: 2
    sort:
      by: priority
      direction: asc
    view: board
    export: null

## Schema Fields
- description: Human-readable explanation
- filters: Issue filtering criteria
- sort: Sort order
- view: Which view to activate
- export: Optional auto-export configuration
- metrics: Optional metric-based filtering
